story:
Choucas, a former police detective, is commissioned by an elderly lady to investigate the disappearance of her blind daughter, Marthe. The lady is murdered. Assisted by retired commissioner Haymann, and by secretary Charlotte, investigator Choucas attempts to unravel the thread of a fraud involving various police services and drug traffickers. During the investigation Choucas is attacked in the apartment of the victim by a certain Pradier; he kills him but his accomplice manages to escape. Back home, Choucas escapes an ambush tended by a certain commissioner Madrier and kills him, with the result of ending up in the viewfinder not only of a mysterious gang, but also of the police.
The story proceeds with a succession of events, including the kidnapping of Charlotte, saved at the last minute by her employer. Choucas will discover that he was maneuvered by the police commissioner Coccioli against his dishonest colleagues, and will risk to leave his life in an attempt to discover the truth and to strip the gang: it will be saved in extremis by policemen.

They began a meticulous search, tracing a web of deceit involving police resources and illicit drug trade. Choucas, facing a perilous situation, was confronted by a violent individual, Pradier, in the victim’s apartment. They hide in a wood where they meet other fugitives, who have been there for months, constantly in fear of being discovered. Out of fear of the German army patrols, they do not dare to leave the forest, even as the food supplies run low. The Polish doctor blows up a bridge, attracting the German troops' attention to the forest. The soldiers come perilously close to the hidden fugitives, but in the last moment have to retreat before the advance of Red Army units.

story: An Arab is captured in the desert after attacking U.S. soldiers in Afghanistan, and then tortured and brutalized in a secret detention center. He finds himself transported to Poland, along with other prisoners. He manages to escape into the vast frozen woodland, a world away from the home he knew. In order to survive, he kills some of those who stray into his path and forages for food both from nature and from those he encounters. A woman gives him shelter, treats his wounds and feeds him before sending him back out into the wilderness. He departs on a white horse and, as the first shoots of spring are seen through the snow, appears to die.

He expired, seemingly devoid of life.

story: As Miguel de Cervantes and his manservant wait to be called before the Spanish Inquisition for putting on a play critical of the tribunal, his fellow inmates subject him to a sham trial of their own in order to justify taking all of the possessions he has with him. Only concerned about the fate of a manuscript, Cervantes mounts his defense in the form of a play, in which he takes the role of Alonso Quijana, an elderly gentleman who has lost his mind and now believes he should go forth as a knight-errant to right the wrongs of the world. Quijana renames himself Don Quixote de La Mancha and sets out with his "squire", Sancho Panza, attacking a windmill he thinks is a giant, and going to an inn, where he meets, woos, and tries to save Aldonza, a world-weary serving wench and prostitute, who he sees as the ideal woman and calls Dulcinea. Quijana's niece, Antonia, is concerned about the effect her uncle's behavior might have on her upcoming  marriage to Sanson Carrasco, a rational man who the local priest convinces to try to rid Quinana of his delusions. Carrasco eventually succeeds, but the shock of the cure leaves Quijana on the brink of death. A visit from Sancho revives him, but he thinks his adventures were all a dream, until Aldonza visits and gets him to remember. As Don Quixote, Sancho, and Aldonza prepare to go off to have more adventures, Don Quixote drops dead, having accomplished little other that providing Aldonza with a fantasy that makes her difficult life a bit more bearable. Back in the dungeon, the inmates return the manuscript to Cervantes as he and his manservant leave to face the Inquisition.
view1:
The Inquisition’s shadow fell upon Miguel de Cervantes and his loyal servant. They stood poised, awaiting summons – a trial predicated on exposing the tribunal’s judgment. The inmates, a collection of souls, orchestrated a deceptive performance, securing the man’s belongings. Cervantes, consumed by a manuscript’s importance, began crafting a play, embodying Alonso Quijana, a wizened veteran adrift in a world of delusion. Quijana, embracing this knightly persona, declared himself Don Quixote, a former gentleman consumed by chivalric fervor. He mounted a challenge to a windmill, believing it a formidable adversary, and ventured to a tavern, seeking solace in the company of Sancho Panza, his squire.

Their travels were fraught with encounters. Quijana wooed Aldonza, a woman of quiet sorrow and a certain allure, framing her as the embodiment of ideal beauty. Antonia, Cervantes’ niece, harbored anxieties about her marriage prospects to Sanson Carrasco, a man of sharp intellect and a fervent desire to subdue Quijana’s madness. Carrasco’s efforts proved successful, yet the sudden shift in Quijana’s perspective left him weakened.

Then, Sancho arrived, a pragmatic man brimming with a simple perspective. He revived Quijana, declaring his adventures merely a fabrication. Yet, Aldonza, with a gentle touch, stirred within the old man a flicker of remembrance.  As Don Quixote, Cervantes and Sancho set forth, towards the looming tribunal.  The manuscript was returned, and with it, the lines of their journey abruptly ended. 

Back within the cold confines of the dungeon, the inmates prepared to face the inevitable. Cervantes and his servant departed, ready to confront the Inquisition’s wrath.  The manuscript, a symbol of their shared endeavor, lay within the darkness, a testament to a peculiar reality.

story:
Tarzan receives a request from Jane, who is helping out on the British home front in World War II, to locate a rare plant-derived serum that can save the lives of many service members. He sets off into the Sahara, which is the shortest route to the place where the plants can be found. Boy and Cheetah tag along, and soon they are joined by a rambunctious horse and traveling magician Connie Bryce (Nancy Kelly), who has been entertaining Allied soldiers in the region.
The group travels to Connie's next destination, a small Arab kingdom in the desert. story:
After barely escaping with his life from an archaeological dig in Tikal, Guatemala, Dr. Henry Jones Jr. makes his way back to New York. There he learns of the recent discovery of the mysterious writings of a missing British explorer, Colonel Percy Fawcett.
Though Colonel Fawcett himself still remains missing, his rediscovered work tells a story that could drastically change history and challenge several firmly held scientific beliefs. Within those pages, an incredible picture begins to take shape of a long lost city in the jungles of Brazil and the apparently true legend of a red-headed race, possibly descended from ancient Celtic Druids.
Fascinated by such a prospect, and with the lovely Deidre Campbell at his side, Indiana Jones sets out for the Amazon. However, as usual, getting there will prove to be the true adventure. And if he does manage to survive the journey, who can tell what dangers await within the mythical city itself.

After a harrowing ordeal from Tikal, Guatemala, Dr. Henry Jones Jr. traveled onward. He soon encountered reports concerning the exploration of Colonel Percy Fawcett. These accounts spoke of a significant find – writings penned by the British explorer.

Fawcett himself remained elusive, yet his work held the potential for monumental shifts in understanding. Inside the documents, a detailed map emerged, revealing a lost city deep within the rainforests of Brazil. It was linked to a compelling legend – a story of a distinct, strikingly colored people, perhaps tracing roots back to ancient Celtic Druids.

Driven by a deep curiosity, Indiana Jones, accompanied by Deidre Campbell, commenced a journey into the Amazon. The challenges of the trek were immediately apparent. It was clear this expedition wouldn’t be a simple endeavor; there was a distinct possibility of encountering perils within the city’s mysteries.

story:
In 1925, an American archaeologist, Desmond Jordan moves to Africa, seeking the "Speaking Mountain". This brings him into the middle of the Sahara desert, where he meets some deserters from the French Foreign Legion. Jordan escapes with Orso (Bear) from a siege by Ryker, a lieutenant of the battalion, and moves towards the mountain.
Ryker and El Hallem, the head of the local tribes, pursue Jordan, who has gone blind while approaching the mountain. The lieutenant gives vent to his violence, murdering some locals and sparing only their queen, Anthea. Later she cures Jordan's blindness and, together with a redeemed El Hallem, helps the archeologist to defeat Ryker.  Eventually, Jordan helps Anthea and Orso discover the secret of the mountain.

Jordan secured the assistance of Bear, a companion, and began his ascent towards the mountain’s peak.

The lieutenant’s actions sparked a brutal campaign, resulting in the deaths of several civilians and the selective preservation of Anthea, the queen.  After a period of healing, Anthea’s intervention proved crucial; she restored Jordan’s sight and collaborated with Ryker to confront the lieutenant.  Together, they ultimately confronted Ryker and achieved victory.  Finally, Jordan helped Anthea and Bear uncover the mountain’s hidden history.

story: Edison (Carrot Top) is a poor, failed inventor and surf bum who has spent his rent money on another unsuccessful invention. After failing to make money at a variety of jobs, Edison soon runs into a wealthy business magnate Armand McMillan (Jack Warden), whose car has broken down on the side of the road. After Edison uses his inventions to assist Armand, the old man becomes impressed with his ingenuity, and the two go surfing together and quickly become friends. When Armand passes away shortly thereafter, he leaves Edison 45% of the shares in his large invention corporation, and leaves Bradford (Larry Miller), his jealous nephew and only living relative, a surfboard as his only inheritance. Bradford attempts to derail Edison's success by stealing his formula for glow in the dark, which does not exist in the world of the film. Bradford shares it with a consumer who covers himself in it and alleges that Edison's prize invention—a portable TV/TV dinner combo—leaks radiation. When Edison reveals that radiation causes sickness and death, but not a literal glowing, the company is saved, Bradford is arrested, and Grace Kosik (Raquel Welch) makes a deal with the company to testify against Bradford. In the end, Edison appoints his girlfriend Natalie Stockwell (Courtney Thorne-Smith) to run the company.

The company was saved, Bradford was apprehended, and Grace Kosik, a renowned actress, entered into a deal with the corporation.  Ultimately, Edison chose Natalie Stockwell – his girlfriend – to lead the company.

Ben is told that he has been given a second chance from God and to begin work as a groundskeeper at the local mental hospital. story:

Her acquaintance "Uncle Bud" shows up. Calling himself an ex-cop, he has long been hatching a scheme to kidnap a rich man's child and needs somebody like Collins to help carry it out.

story:
The film is set at a United States Army base in Kentucky at the end of 1944, during World War II. 
The protagonists are First Sergeant Vic Puccinelli and Private First Class Alvin Korwin, who were partners in a nightclub song-and-dance act before joining the Army.
Puccinelli wants to be transferred from his dull job to active duty overseas, but is refused transfer and is to be promoted to Warrant Officer. Korwin wants a pass to see his wife and new baby. In addition, they have to rehearse for the base talent show and avoid the wrath of Alvin's platoon sergeant, Sergeant McVey.
Along the way they both sing a few songs, and they do an impression of Bing Crosby and Barry Fitzgerald by recreating a scene from Going My Way (1944) for the talent show. Further complications include a Post Exchange worker who is pregnant, a company commander who gets all his information from his wife, a scheming supply sergeant, and a defective Coca-Cola machine.
view1:
The scene unfolds at a US Army post in Kentucky, late in 1944.  A significant period of the war is in play. 
First Sergeant Vic Puccinelli and Private First Class Alvin Korwin, previously collaborators in a lively entertainment venture, found themselves drafted into the military. 
Puccinelli envisioned a move to active service overseas, a desire fueled by a desire for change, but his request was thwarted. Instead, he’d be elevated to the rank of Warrant Officer. Korwin, meanwhile, sought a chance to reconnect with his wife and burgeoning child. 
Their rehearsals were frequent, performed with a spirited energy, acutely aware of the presence of Sergeant McVey, the platoon sergeant. 
The duo skillfully transitioned into musical performances, mirroring the essence of a bygone era, recreating a pivotal moment from ‘Going My Way’ (1944) – a performance intended for the base’s talent showcase.  
The situation became considerably more intricate.  A Post Exchange employee, pregnant, provided crucial information. A company commander relied solely on his partner’s insights. A cunning supply sergeant plotted and manipulated. A malfunctioning Coca-Cola machine disrupted the proceedings.

story: The film, made in wartime, celebrates the work of the Stage Door Canteen, created in New York City as a recreational center for both American and Allied servicemen on leave to socialize with, be entertained or served by Broadway celebrities. The storyline follows several women who volunteer for the Canteen and must adhere to strict rules of conduct, the most important of which is that their job is to provide friendly companionship to and be dance partners for the (often nervous) men who are soon to be sent into combat. No romantic fraternization is allowed. Eileen is a volunteer who confesses to only becoming involved in the Canteen in order to be discovered by one of the Hollywood stars in attendance. She ultimately finds herself falling in love with one of the soldiers.
view1:
---

The film, born from the shadows of war, honored the Stage Door Canteen. It sprang forth in New York, a haven for servicemen – Americans and those from the Allied side – seeking respite and amusement. This establishment served as a social hub, a place to unwind, perhaps partake in entertainment, or simply be served by the dazzling figures of Broadway’s elite. The narrative centered on several women, each dedicated to the Canteen’s service. Their primary responsibility was to offer comfort and partnership to the men preparing for deployment. Crucially, strict guidelines governed their actions.  The most stringent rule was that their role was to cultivate a supportive relationship – a friendly alliance with the individuals who were soon venturing into the perilous realities of combat.  Romantic connection was strictly forbidden.  Eileen, a volunteer, revealed a secret: she’d entered the Canteen hoping to capture the attention of a prominent Hollywood star.  However, her feelings soon blossomed into a profound affection for one of the soldiers.

story:
A prominent doctor from New England has been murdered, and his young nephew has been convicted of the crime. A seductive, possibly unstable woman named Angela Crispini persuades a private investigator, Tom O'Toole, to look into the case. She claims that the youth is innocent and that "everybody" knows who the real killer is.
O'Toole lives with his sister, Connie, who is convinced Crispini is just using him. O'Toole is determined to get to the bottom of the case, in part due to his contempt for Charley Haggerty, the district attorney.
He discovers that Crispini may be a prostitute and that she also had been romantically involved with Haggerty before him. O'Toole enlists the help of a friendly judge, Murdoch, only to see Crispini seduce and manipulate the judge as well.

story: Young David Carroll takes over the publication of a local newspaper in Vermont. Although he is attracted to Dot, "the most sophisticated girl in town," he marries Allie Parker, daughter of the couple who run the boardinghouse where he lives. Allie remains at home when David goes to New York City to sell a musical he has written. There, Dot, now a successful costume designer, uses her influence to get David's play produced. David and Dot fall in love, but she leaves for Paris when David indicates he will remain true to Allie. He sends for Allie, but when she arrives with her whole family, he decides to follow Dot to Paris.

He dispatched Allie, his lifelong companion, to Paris.  When she arrived, the family – a bustling, warm group – filled the space.  David, however, remained resolute. He decided to follow Dot, his heart leading him to the French capital.

story: Twenty-five-year-old Lucile is the beautiful mistress to Charles, a wealthy, kind-hearted businessman who provides for all her material needs, but for whom she has no true love. When she meets a charming young man her own age, Antoine, she falls in love. He finds her a menial job in a publishing firm, but she can not or will not hold it down. Soon she becomes pregnant with his child. But Charles helps her through her crisis by funding her abortion – against the wishes of Antoine, who nevertheless accepts, even though he planned on moving out of his bachelor flat, the three of them into a soulless concrete block, money being short. In the aftermath, her feelings for the younger Antoine fade. Eventually, she returns to the good-hearted businessman who has patiently waited for her.

story: This third novel of Updike's Rabbit series examines the life of Harry "Rabbit" Angstrom, a one-time high school basketball star, who has reached a paunchy middle-age without relocating from Brewer, Pennsylvania, the poor, fictional city of his birth.  Harry and Janice, his wife of 22 years, live comfortably, having inherited her late father's  Toyota dealership.  He is indeed rich, but Harry's persistent problems—his wife's drinking, his troubled son's schemes, his libido, and spectres from his past—complicate life. Having achieved an opulent lifestyle that would have embarrassed his working-class parents, Harry is not greedy, but neither is he ever quite satisfied.  Harry has grown smitten with a country-club friend's young wife. He worries about Nelson, his indecisive son, a student at Kent State University. Throughout the book, Harry wonders whether his former lover, Ruth, ever gave birth to their illegitimate daughter.

He’s a man, undeniably burdened by age, his physique reflecting a life spent largely rooted in that small town. They possess a comfortable routine, bolstered by the inheritance of her deceased father’s dealership.  Financial stability is a given, yet a persistent undercurrent of unease surrounds him. His son, Nelson, struggles with a collection of anxieties and schemes, mirroring the chaos within him.  The past – shadowy recollections – cast a long shadow.  Harry finds himself caught in a web of feelings, an entanglement with a man from the countryside. He contemplates the possibility of Ruth, a former lover, perhaps with a child born under a different name.  His quiet desperation fuels a constant, low-level agitation.  He observes the world with a detached gaze, acutely aware of the fragility of his circumstances.  The weight of expectation, coupled with a strange, persistent melancholy, defines his present.  He yearns for something more, yet finds himself anchored to the familiar.

story: Mecha, a woman in her 50s with several teenage children and a husband, Gregorio, wants to remain looking young. story: Set in the summer of 1978, Lucy and Norman, a young married couple whose relationship is going through a rough patch, join Norman's boss, Paul, and his Spanish wife, Isabel, on holiday in Basque Country. Located in an isolated area in the middle of the forest, Paul's ancestral home seems the ideal spot for a quiet stay and the chance for Lucy and Norman to sort out their emotional problems. However, their peace is shattered when Paul and Norman discover a cabin in the forest in which a girl with ectrodactyly is imprisoned. story:
A peasant found a devil in his fields, sitting on a fire.  He guessed he was sitting on treasure, and the devil offered it if for two years, half of the crop was his.  The peasant agreed, and said that to prevent disputes, the half above the ground was the devil's, and the half below the peasant's.  When the devil agreed, the peasant planted turnips.
When harvest time came, the devil saw his leaves and the peasant's turnips, and said they must do it the other way round the next year.  The peasant agreed and planted wheat.  At harvest, the devil found he got nothing but stubble.  Having been outwitted twice, he retreated into the earth in a fury, and the peasant took the treasure.
view1:
A solitary farmer stumbled upon a malevolent presence within his cultivated fields. He surmised the figure was perched upon a scorching bed of embers. He believed it held riches, and the entity offered a generous portion for a protracted two-year commitment. The farmer accepted, accepting a conditional pact: half of the harvest would be his.  The agreement served as a safeguard, ensuring no conflict arose regarding the distribution of the bounty.  Upon this arrangement, the devil conceded, and the farmer cultivated turnips.

As the reaping season arrived, the devil observed the leafy growth and the turnips cultivated by the peasant. He recognized a discrepancy – the arrangement was reversed.  The next year, the devil discovered a barren landscape, devoid of the harvested produce.  Consumed by bitterness and rage, the entity retreated into the soil, a furious tempest.  The farmer, however, retrieved the stolen treasure.

The peasant planted turnips.

Harvest time arrived. The devil saw the turnips and the seeds. The devil said the seeds must be planted in the opposite direction. The peasant agreed. The peasant planted wheat.

Harvest time. The devil found no treasure. The devil’s leaves were covered in stubble. The devil retreated into the earth. The peasant took the treasure.

story: Satan has been cast out of Hell and banished to Earth under decree of Heaven. He can return only after overseeing a series of temptations. However, for every soul who gives in to his tempting, one hundred years are added to his sentence. For every soul who resists, one thousand years are subtracted from his sentence. The film follows Satan throughout much of recorded history, focusing mainly on four short episodes. First he tempts Judas to betray Jesus, then he goes on to influence the Spanish Inquisition, spark the French Revolution and finally he causes the Finnish Civil War of 1918 to occur.
view1:
Satan’s exile began with a commanding proclamation from Heaven. He was stripped of his dominion within the infernal realm and confined to this planet – a consequence of divine decree. His return was contingent upon the successful completion of a series of trials. For each soul that succumbed to his allure, a significant period of time was accrued to his total. Conversely, for those who steadfastly refused his advances, years were diminished from his lifespan.

The narrative traces Satan’s journey through the ages, primarily examining four distinct episodes. Initially, he orchestrated a scheme involving Judas, subtly guiding him toward betrayal. Subsequently, he exerted considerable influence over the Spanish Inquisition, fostering division and conflict. The French Revolution followed, ignited by his actions.  Finally, a brutal conflict erupted within Finland, culminating in a devastating civil war of 1918.

Each action was meticulously planned and executed, meticulously charting Satan’s trajectory.  The film depicts his pervasive presence throughout history’s recorded narrative – primarily focusing on these four pivotal moments.  He relentlessly pursued his objectives, demanding unwavering compliance.

story: Marie is 19 and is bored in her little suburban life with no future. In a café, she meets Gérard, a beautiful brown frimeur and voluble, who has no trouble seducing. Blinded by love, too candid, Mary decides to leave her parents and her clerk job to live with the man she considers as the love of her life. But Gerard is a pimp, who soon forces her into prostitution. By "home visit" first, in the street or in the Bois de Boulogne then, the young woman gradually discovers a world of decay and violence.
view1:
Marie, a nineteen-year-old, felt profoundly restless. Her existence in the quiet suburb held no promise of a future. A café served as a momentary respite, a place where she encountered Gérard. He was strikingly handsome, a brown man with an easy, conversational manner.  His charm was immediate, a captivating display of boldness. Driven by an intense, almost overwhelming, affection, Marie felt compelled to abandon her family and her mundane job at the clerk’s office.  She resolved to relocate to Gérard, to become wholly devoted to him.

However, Gerard proved to be a figure of shadowed realities.  He was a pimp, and quickly, she found herself entangled in a dangerous situation.  A ‘home visit’ – a brief appearance on the street or within the Bois de Boulogne – soon led her into a disturbing landscape.  The world around her shifted, revealing a stark reality of decay and brutal force.

story: Arlette, a country girl and illegitimate daughter of the minister of justice, travels to Paris for the first time. An accordion player, she hopes to make a career in music. She unwittingly escapes Gérard Laurent the civil service minder her father has secretly sent to watch her and falls in with some bohemians from Monmartre. After Arlette and her friends get arrested for busking she meets and falls in love with Gérard. Her father's resignation from his position at last allows him to acknowledge her.
view1: Arlette, a woman born in the rural countryside, arrived in Paris with a quiet purpose. She was a daughter of a justice official, a lineage steeped in tradition and rural life. Her destination was the city of lights, with a singular ambition – to establish a career in music.  A cheerful accordion player, she initially sought to begin her musical pursuits.  However, her journey unexpectedly veered from her planned route.  She stumbled out of her father’s care, a secret she’d kept carefully guarded, and found herself entangled with a group of artists residing in the charming district of Monmartre.  Their collective arrest for playing music – a clandestine act – brought her into contact with a captivating man, Gérard Laurent.  Their connection deepened, blossoming into a passionate affection.  Her father, burdened by a decision, finally relinquished his role as a watchful figure.  He acknowledged her presence, a turning point in her life.

story:

He tries to send her to a convent but she escapes to Paris to live with her brother. On the train she meets Daniel, a journalist. Agnes thinks her brother is a rich artist but he's actually a poor guide in the Balzac Museum.
Agnes needs money and enters an amateur striptease contest. Daniel is covering the contest for his magazine.

story:
After a shootout with dozens of assassins, Wong Kom, bodyguard to Chot Petchpantakarn, the wealthiest man in Asia, finds his client killed.
Chaichol, the son and heir to the family fortune, fires the bodyguard and takes it upon himself to find the killers. He's then ambushed, and the rest of the bodyguard team is wiped out. Chaichol, however, comes out of it alive, and finds himself in a Bangkok slum, living with a volunteer car-accident rescue squad and falling in love with tomboyish Pok.
Meanwhile, Wong Kom is working to clear his name, and stay ahead of the chief villain and his bumbling gang of henchmen.
view1:
Wong Kom, his duty as Chot Petchpantakarn’s steadfast shield, found a chilling revelation – his client, a man of immense wealth, was deceased. A brutal confrontation had unfolded, a swirling chaos of attackers. Chaichol, the son and heir to the considerable fortune, deliberately instigated the violence, launching a furious assault. He then, with a determined resolve, launched a pursuit, a relentless mission to identify the perpetrators. 

Chaichol, driven by an insistent need to restore order, immediately engaged in a perilous pursuit. He was subsequently targeted by a hostile force, the rest of the bodyguard crew vanished without a trace. Despite the devastating setback, Chaichol emerged unscathed, deposited into a grimy, impoverished district of Bangkok. He was granted temporary residence by a compassionate volunteer rescue squad, a stark contrast to his former life. Simultaneously, Wong Kom wrestled with a persistent and formidable adversary, a relentless chief of criminal activity.

story:
A woman's mistakes come back to haunt her in a terrifying and very literal manner in this mind-bending thriller. Dr. Samantha Goodman (Kate Greenhouse) is a clinical psychiatrist who works with patients at an institution for the criminally insane. Things have not been rosy for Sam lately—she's been violently attacked by one of her patients, her marriage to husband David (Gordon Currie) is in bad shape, and she has an inoperable brain tumor that's growing at an alarming rate.
Sam needs a weekend away from the city, but what David has set up isn't especially relaxing for her—a short holiday at a remote cabin, where David will be editing his latest book with the help of Sam's younger, attractive sister Melody (Iris Graham). As Sam watches sparks begin to fly between her sister and her husband, Harlan Pyne (Aidan Devine) and his friend Adrian (Dov Tiefenbach) break into the cabin and announce their presence by shooting Sam's pet dog.
Harlan is a convicted sex offender and murderer who was placed under Sam's care in the institution and wasn't happy with the experimental treatment he received; having escaped, he and Adrian have tracked her down and decide to take revenge by forcing Sam, Melody, and David to participate in a series of strange and humiliating games.
view1:
Samantha Goodman, a psychiatrist, resided within a psychiatric facility dedicated to individuals grappling with severe mental states.  A palpable sense of unease permeated her life; her marriage to David Currie suffered a significant downturn, and a formidable brain tumor was rapidly expanding within her.  

She requested a respite from the urban sprawl; a weekend getaway was arranged, but David’s plans weren’t conducive to comfort.  Instead, she found herself at a secluded cabin, a space intended for a holiday with her younger sister, Melody Graham. Iris, her sister, was there, radiating a pleasant energy.  

As Sam observed the burgeoning connection between Melody and Harlan Pyne, a man with a checkered past, and his friend, Aidan Devine, a skilled marksman, they breached the cabin’s perimeter.  They unleashed a devastating attack; Sam’s beloved canine companion was fatally shot.

Harlan Pyne, a notorious offender with a history of disturbing acts, was a figure she’d encountered during her tenure at the institution.  He and Aidan had meticulously planned a campaign of retribution, demanding Sam, Melody, and David participate in bizarre, deliberately humiliating exercises.

The games were humiliating. The games continued. Sam’s brain tumor grew rapidly. The holiday at the remote cabin was interrupted. The game series concluded. Harlan and Adrian were apprehended.

story: The film follows five simultaneous, loosely linked plot lines, that intertwine and scramble together. A man (Tadanobu Asano) keeps killing his wife (Reika Hashimoto) and burying her in the woods only to find her alive, furious, and waiting for him when he returns home. A suburban family's life is disrupted when the father (Ittoku Kishibe) is permanently hypnotized into believing he is a bird and tries to learn how to fly. A trio of aimless youth pass time by burgling houses. A murderous advertising executive (Kyōko Koizumi) tries to imagine ideas for commercials. The stories clash together through the intervention of a thuggish hitman (Vinnie Jones) and his translator (Yoshiyoshi Arakawa).

story: Lissy Schroeder, a working-class girl in Berlin, marries Alfred, a clerk.  In 1932, Alfred is fired by his Jewish boss.  Despite having ties to the Communist party through Lissy's brother Paul, the previously apolitical Alfred joins the Nazi party.  After Hitler gains power, Paul is shot by the Nazis, causing Lissy to question the country's and her husband's politics and where her loyalties truly lie.

In 1932, Alfred faced dismissal from his employer – a Jewish individual. Despite a connection to the socialist circles stemming from her brother, Paul, Alfred initially remained neutral about the political landscape and the direction of their lives. As Hitler ascended to power, Paul was tragically wounded, prompting Lissy to wrestle with the nation’s and her husband’s principles and her own sense of allegiance.

story: The families of Juli, Nora and Beni were resettled during the communist rule to a small village in no man's land on the edge of a swamp. In present-day Albania, Juli works at her uncle Beni's café Bota. She lives with her grandmother Noje and takes care of her. Nora, Juli's friend, becomes Beni's mistress. Beni wants to expand the café and tries to attract new customers. With the expansion of the highway near the village, the peaceful life of the protagonists ends.

story: La Chèvre features Depardieu as tough-guy private detective Campana, hired to find Marie, the daughter of a rich businessman, who has mysteriously disappeared while vacationing in Mexico. The case turns out to be complicated – several attempts to find her have already failed. A psychologist, Meyer, who works for the businessman, suggests a plan: Marie is known to be extremely unlucky and accident-prone; therefore, the psychologist advises sending someone equally unlucky and accident-prone to find her on the theory that what happened to her may also happen to him, and thus, following her steps while the detective tags along, the daughter can be found and returned home. Richard's character Perrin is an awkward, accident-prone accountant who works for the businessman, and is chosen to implement the scheme while being made to believe that HE is actually in charge of the investigation. While Campana does not believe in luck and is extremely skeptical about the plan's success, he goes along with it. The adventures of the serious detective and unlucky guy begin, with, amazingly, each misfortune Perrin suffers along the way bringing the duo one step closer each time to finding their quarry...
view1: The investigator, Campana, possessed a reputation for unwavering resolve. He was a private detective, operating in the shadows, and his client, a man named Marie, had vanished from Mexico. The search had been fruitless – numerous attempts to locate her had yielded nothing. A psychologist, Meyer, connected to the businessman, proposed a peculiar strategy. Marie was habitually prone to mishaps, a fact Meyer believed would aid their efforts. Meyer suggested sending someone else, equally clumsy, to pursue the girl’s whereabouts. Campana, however, remained unconvinced. He dismissed the notion of luck as a fallacy; he preferred a methodical approach. Perrin, the accountant, was chosen – a man of awkwardness and frequent errors. Perrin was assigned to lead the investigation. He was tasked with believing he held the key to success, even as he suffered numerous setbacks. The duo’s journey began, a relentless pursuit. Each misfortune of Perrin escalated the situation, bringing them closer to their goal.

story: Wealthy American businessman Jack Moore (Richard Gere) is on a trip to China attempting to put together a satellite communications deal as part of a joint venture with the Chinese government. Before the deal can be finalized, Moore is framed for the murder of a powerful Chinese general's daughter, and the satellite contract is instead awarded to Moore's competitor, Gerhardt Hoffman (Ulrich Matschoss). Moore's court-appointed lawyer, Shen Yuelin (Bai Ling), initially does not believe his claims of innocence, but the pair gradually unearth evidence that not only vindicates Moore, but implicates powerful figures within the Chinese central government administration, exposing undeniable conspiracy and corruption. Shen manages to convince several high-ranking Chinese officials to release evidence that proves Moore's innocence. Moore is quickly released from prison while the conspirators responsible for framing him are arrested. At the airport, Moore asks Shen to leave China with him, but she decides to stay, as the case has opened her eyes to the injustices rife throughout China. She does admit, however, that meeting Moore has changed her life, and she now considers him a part of her family. They both share a heartfelt hug on the airport runway, before Moore departs for America.
view1: Jack Moore, a prominent American tycoon, embarked on a mission to forge a vital partnership with the Chinese government. The satellite communications initiative was central to this endeavor, a joint venture conceived with the tacit approval of Beijing. Before the arrangement solidified, a terrible accusation arose – the murder of a prominent Chinese general’s daughter. Consequently, the contract went to a rival, Gerhardt Hoffman, a man known for his ambition.  Moore’s legal counsel, Shen Yuelin, initially remained skeptical, unsure of his own defense. However, a painstaking investigation began, revealing a tangled web of evidence. The evidence powerfully affirmed Moore’s claim – he was innocent.  Shen skillfully maneuvered several powerful figures within the Chinese central administration to yield crucial information.  This revelation swiftly led to the arrest of those responsible for the framing.  Moore was released from prison with remarkable speed.  He requested Shen’s presence with him, but she remained steadfast.  She’d found something profoundly unsettling, a darkness she couldn’t ignore.  The encounter had irrevocably altered her perspective, and she felt an undeniable connection to Moore. They embraced, a brief, heartfelt moment on the airport tarmac.  Moore prepared to leave, intending to return to America.  Shen, however, insisted she remain, drawn into the intricate and troubling patterns of China.  She confessed, quietly, that this experience had fundamentally shifted her understanding of the world.  The meeting had proven to be a turning point, opening a door to a new, complicated reality.  She recognized Moore as a significant part of her life now, a family member in a way she hadn't fully appreciated before.

Several high-ranking officials released information. The conspirators were arrested. Moore was released from prison. Moore requested Shen’s departure. Shen accepted. They shared a hug on the airport runway. Moore departed for America.

story:
A fishery is seeking court action against a local chemical factory for polluting the water. The mysterious chemical company hires lawyer Jackie Lung to find information that will discredit the fishery. He employs his arms dealer friend, Wong to woo the fishery owner, Miss Yip, to try to convince her to settle out of court.
Lung also brings in goofy inventor and professional criminal, Tung, to bug her apartment. Unfortunately, Wong and Tung are unaware of each other's roles and soon come into confrontation, while Lung tries to maintain the peace.
Wong falls for Miss Yip, whilst Lung woos her cousin, Miss Wen, an environmental scientist who is going to testify on Miss Yip's behalf. The three men inadvertently discover that the chemical company is just a facade for a narcotics empire, run by Hua Hsien-Wu (Yuen Wah). They soon come up against Hua's thugs, and ultimately infiltrate the factory for a showdown with Hua himself and his henchman - martial arts master.
view1:

The unfamiliar company, known as ‘Shadow Chemicals,’ hired Jackie Lung to uncover evidence designed to undermine the operation. Lung’s associate, Wong, cultivated Miss Yip’s interest, attempting to persuade her to resolve the dispute through legal channels.

Lung’s team also included the eccentric inventor, Tung, and the skilled criminal, Wong. They infiltrated Miss Yip’s residence, a calculated maneuver. Wong’s intentions were misplaced, leading to a clash with the others; Lung worked to maintain a calm atmosphere.

Miss Yip, captivated by Tung’s charm, began to show signs of attraction to him. Lung, meanwhile, attempted to woo Miss Wen, an environmentalist, who was slated to present evidence crucial to the case. The trio stumbled upon a disturbing truth: ‘Shadow Chemicals’ was a cleverly constructed deception, concealing a far more sinister operation – a narcotics syndicate controlled by Hua Hsien-Wu (Yuen Wah). They were subsequently confronted by Hua’s ruthlessly armed guards, leading to a tense confrontation with the mastermind himself and his enforcer. A battle ensued, culminating in a decisive confrontation with Hua and his lieutenant within the factory itself.

story:
Wedding planner/caterer Max is staging a wedding at a 17th-century chateau, in the course of which he must deal with a volatile, often foul-mouthed assistant, missing staff, incompetent waiters, a demanding, egocentric groom, iffy electrical system, a rebellious substitute DJ, and a whole lot more.
Interwoven with his professional woes are his personal ones. He is on a trial separation from his wife and his French grammarian brother-in-law, who is also one of his waiters, is a former admirer of the bride. Max's other assistant is his mistress, who threatens to end their relationship and starts hitting on one of the waiters to prove it. And it's Max's birthday.
At the end of a string of safely negotiated disasters a runaway fireworks display and a crashed electrical system at the height of the event finally make him give up in despair and walk away... only to discover that his staff have surmounted the obstacles to create an outstanding, one-of-a-kind wedding celebration, Le sens de la fête: the meaning of the party.
view1:

His assistant, a prickly individual, clashed constantly with him, causing a lot of friction. The staff were disorganized, the waiters clumsy, and the groom was demanding, with a peculiar attitude. The electrical wiring was problematic; it flickered and sputtered. A substitute DJ was also present, creating chaos. A mysterious mistress added another layer of complexity, threatening to sever their bond and launching a targeted attack on one of the waiters. It was Max’s birthday, a significant moment.

A cascade of problems unfolded. A runaway fireworks display erupted, sending sparks into the air. Simultaneously, a significant electrical failure occurred, creating a temporary blackout. The entire situation felt hopeless. Max, overwhelmed, retreated. He found himself deserted, feeling defeated. However, the staff, working diligently, managed to produce a spectacular celebration. It was a unique and memorable affair, embodying a powerful sense of joy. Le sens de la fête – the meaning of the party – had been achieved.

story: Eva Norová goes to visit her aunt Pa for her 60th birthday. Pa's wish is to learn how to grow the kind of roses that her neighbour, factory owner Záhorský has cultivated. However, aunt Pa is not on friendly terms with her neighbour. Eva applies for a job as a secretary in order to steal the instructions for growing the roses. Meanwhile, Eva's brother Michal, who has fallen in love with Záhorský's daughter Eliška, also makes his way to the Záhorský residence. Eva in turn falls in love with the Záhorskýs' secretary, Jiří Kučera, who has nestled his way into the family in order to win back his stolen family jewels. When Eva brings the instructions for growing the roses to her aunt, she finds out that she already got them a week earlier from Záhorský's daughter Eliška, and Eva returns the instructions. In the end everything turns out well, the Záhorskýs become friends with aunt Pa and offer her the rose growing instructions themselves, Jiří's family jewels are returned, Michal is engaged to Eliška and Eva gets together with Jiří.
view1:
Eva ventured forth, a mission in mind. Her aunt, Pa, was slated for a special occasion – her 60th birthday. Pa’s fervent desire was for Pa to master the art of cultivating roses, a specific variety that bordered the property of Záhorský, the factory owner. A strained relationship existed between Eva and Záhorský; their interactions were habitually contentious.

Eva sought employment, a position as a secretary. This was a deliberate strategy; she intended to acquire the knowledge necessary to acquire the secrets of the roses.  She applied for the role, a means to steal the detailed instructions. Her brother, Michal, a soul consumed by longing for Eliška, the daughter of Záhorský’s heir, arrived at the residence.

Eva’s affections began to deepen, unexpectedly, with the secretary, Jiří Kučera.   Jiří’s presence was a subtle, insistent force, weaving his way into the family’s sphere.  He was drawn to Eliška, her beauty a tantalizing target.

After gathering the rose-growing secrets, Eva discovered a startling truth: she’d already possessed the knowledge.  She swiftly returned the instructions to Eliška, a calculated maneuver. The Záhorsky family, initially wary, began to soften, offering their expertise in rose cultivation.  Eliška’s engagement was secured, and Michal’s affections were secured.

The situation spiraled into a harmonious resolution.  The Záhorsky family embraced Eva, and they agreed to share their knowledge.  Jerí’s family jewels were restored, and Michal was presented to Eliška.  Eva’s own life
view2:
Eva Norová visited her aunt Pa. Pa’s wish was to learn rose growing techniques. Eva applied for a secretary position. The position was intended to obtain rose growing instructions.

Eva’s brother, Michal, visited the Záhorský residence. He was interested in the roses. Záhorský’s daughter, Eliška, had grown roses.

Eva received instructions. She knew Eliška had provided the instructions. Eva returned the instructions.

The Záhorskýs became friends with Eva. They offered rose growing instructions. Michal was engaged to Eliška.

Jiří Kučera, the secretary, befriended the Záhorskýs. He sought to win back his stolen jewels.

The jewels were returned. The Záhorskýs offered Eva the instructions.

Eva and Jiří connected. They formed a relationship.

story: Novelist Soso (Ramaz Giorgobiani) goes to his publishing house in an attempt to find someone interested in publishing his latest manuscript. The employees shuffle the author's manuscript around their office from person to person, but everyone seems to be too busy to actually read it. Soso ultimately discovers that the employees are wrapped up in anything but their direct duties and responsibilities so much that not even a giant structural flaw in the building can get their attention. The movie is an allegory of Soviet-time bureaucracy and Soviet system as a whole. At the end of the film, the house collapses and the employees move to another, brand new and modern building. However, that does not mean they change their attitude towards their work ...

story: Nineteen-year-old Maria Morzeck dreams of studying Slavistics, but her hopes are shattered when her brother, Dieter, is sent to prison after being convicted of sedition against the state. She cannot enter college, and becomes a waitress. Maria meets and falls in love with Paul Deister, an older, married man who turns out to be the judge who convicted her brother. Their affair ends when Deister is exposed as hypocritical and corrupt. After Dieter's release, he learns of his sister's relationship with the judge and assaults her. Eventually, Maria distances herself from both of them, and decides to pursue her forgotten dream.

story:
1914, German advance through Belgium: the young war volunteer Alexander 'Alex' Haller (Schell) is given water by an equally young Belgian woman (Berger). 
1917, Third Battle of Flanders: Alex, now a 2nd lieutenant, is tired about the propaganda at the Home Front, so he spends his furlough in the hinterland of the Western Front. 
While boarding in a brothel, he meets the young woman again. They fall in love. 
Late 1918, German retreat after the Armistice: Engele and Alex meet again only to be harassed by a Belgian mob. Shortly prior to be hanged by the mob, a group of passing Belgian soldiers, tired about killing, saves them. End of the tale.
view1:
Alexander Haller, a young man, was given a drink by a Belgian girl named Berger. 

The Third Battle of Flanders wore him down; he felt the force of the news, the relentless appeals from the home.  His leave, a precious time, was spent in a quiet, wooded area – a secluded spot.

He encountered Berger again, and a spark ignited – a nascent affection began to bloom. 

After the German withdrawal, a change occurred; he was now a lieutenant, feeling disheartened by the constant displays of propaganda.  He sought respite, retreating into the shadows of the Western Front. 

While seeking refuge in a dimly lit establishment, he recognized the girl he’d first met.  Their connection deepened, an undeniable pull. 

The relentless pressure of the war continued; the Belgian mob grew insistent.  His fate was sealed – he was targeted, and soon, he was condemned.

But a swift rescue arrived.  A group of soldiers, weary from the bloodshed, intervened, altering the sequence of events. 

The tale concluded – a poignant moment of solidarity, a desperate act of mercy

story: The novel is from the point of view of the Austrian countess Martha Althaus over the course of four wars. During the Second Italian War of Independence, at age 19, Althaus loses her husband, the count Arno Dotzky, and decides that she is against war. Her second husband, Baron Friedrich Tilling, shares her pacifistic convictions even though he is an officer in the Austrian army. He fought in the Second Schleswig War alongside Prussia in 1864, and in the Austro-Prussian War in 1866. Althaus' sisters and brother die of cholera because of the war, and her father dies of grief after losing his children. Friedrich then retires from the army to support Althaus' peace activism. During the Franco-Prussian War, Friedrich is shot while staying in Paris because he is suspected of being a Prussian spy. Althaus' son from her first marriage, Rudolf, begins to follow in his mother's footsteps.
view1: Martha Althaus, a woman of Austrian lineage, witnessed four wars unfold. At twenty-nine, her world fractured – her husband, Arno Dotzky, was lost in the Second Italian War of Independence. A resolve solidified within her: she refused to participate in conflict. Her subsequent partner, Baron Friedrich Tilling, mirrored her beliefs, though he served as a military officer within the Austrian ranks. He’d battled alongside Prussia in the Second Schleswig War, and later in the Austro-Prussian War. Her siblings succumbed to cholera, victims of the bloodshed, and her father, consumed by grief, passed away following the loss of his children. Friedrich, disheartened by the war, retreated from the military to champion her cause.  During the Franco-Prussian War, Friedrich was struck by gunfire in Paris – suspicion of Prussian espionage led to his capture. Rudolf, her son from her first marriage, began to investigate her activism.

story: After graduating from the École nationale d'administration, which trains France's leaders in the public and private sectors, Arthur Vlaminck lands a job as speechwriter in the Foreign Ministry. Existing senior advisers do not welcome a talented newcomer who may become a competitor but his abilities are recognised by the Minister and, most important, by Maupas, the career official heading the department. That said, coming up with the right words for the constantly changing world situation and the constantly changing reactions of the Minister proves no easy task. He gets hastily written drafts past Maupas, and past other senior advisers who rubbish them, only to find that the Minister's needs have changed. The film ends in February 2003 with a re-enactment of the actual speech by Dominique de Villepin to the UN Security Council, at which he contradicted claims by Colin Powell and Donald Rumsfeld and argued passionately for disarmament of Iraq but not invasion.
view1:
Arthur Vlaminck stepped into the world of government, a new path laid out by the École nationale d’administration. He was assigned to the Foreign Ministry, a position meant to be a crucial role. The existing advisors, seasoned professionals, weren’t keen on this bright newcomer. They sensed a potential challenge, a rival who might steal their attention. Yet, the Minister recognized Vlaminck’s worth, and crucially, Maupas, the senior official, offered his support. 

The task of crafting the perfect words proved frustrating. He’d receive drafts, quickly discarded as inadequate. Other advisors dismissed them as clumsy, failing to grasp the nuances of the situation. The Minister’s desires shifted with relentless speed.  He was tasked with presenting the message, and the reactions of the Minister were a constant variable. 

The film unfolded in February 2003, marking a pivotal moment. A meticulously recreated scene played out: Dominique de Villepin delivered a speech to the United Nations Security Council.  His words clashed with Colin Powell and Donald Rumsfeld’s assertions about Iraq’s disarmament, culminating in a passionate plea for a different approach – one without military action.  It was a significant shift in diplomatic strategy.

The speech was delivered to the UN Security Council. Dominique de Villepin delivered a speech. He contradicted claims by Colin Powell and Donald Rumsfeld. He argued for disarmament of Iraq, but not invasion.

The speech ended in February 2003. A re-enactment of the speech was performed. It was the speech by Dominique de Villepin to the UN Security Council.

story:
Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson come out of retirement to investigate a mysterious murder. They find that an American criminal organisation called The Scowrers has asked evil mastermind Professor Moriarty to wreak vengeance on John Douglas, the informant who sent them to prison. Holmes outsmarts Moriarty, solves the murder and brings Moriarty to justice.
Like all the films featuring Wontner as Holmes, this one has a contemporary 1930s setting, making the flashback sequence pitting undercover detective Douglas against the Scowrers somewhat problematical since, historically, the real-life incident on which this sequence is based, Pinkerton operative James McParland's infiltration of the Molly Maguires, occurred in the 1870s, a full half-century earlier.
view1:

Moriarty sought retribution against John Douglas, a pivotal figure who had introduced them to the prison system. Holmes, with his sharp intellect, systematically dismantled Moriarty’s schemes. The investigation yielded a solution, and the criminal mastermind was brought to account.

Like the films featuring Watson as Holmes, this instance took place in a distinctly 1930s world. The flashbacks – depicting a clandestine operation involving undercover detective Douglas confronting the Scowrers – presented a peculiar challenge.  Historically, the events surrounding James McParland’s infiltration of the Molly Maguires in the 1870s provided the foundation for this sequence.  A significant portion of the story hinged on recreating a plausible, albeit fictionalized, account of that earlier incident.

story:
At home in his New York City apartment, John Shaft is tranquilized, then kidnapped and persuaded by threats of physical force, the promise of money, and the lure of a pretty tutor to travel to Africa, assuming the identity of an indigenous language-speaking itinerant worker. His job is to help break a criminal ring that is smuggling immigrants into Europe, then exploiting them. But the villains are tipped off that he is on his way.
Shaft initially passes a test before being hired for the job; the test involves him surviving in a small, overheated room without water, and a floor covered in deep sand, mimicking the supposed conditions of Africa. Shaft covers himself with the sand, thereby avoiding heatstroke and winning the contract from his new employer. Shaft then embarks on a mission to infiltrate and destroy a human trafficking and slavery ring in Africa and France.

He shielded himself completely with the material, successfully circumventing the dangers of the heat and securing the position with his new employer.  Then, he commenced a pursuit – a mission to penetrate and neutralize a trafficking and slavery ring both in Africa and France.

story:

One hundred years later, the tree she was chained to and burned still stands with no one daring to destroy it.  The curse remains by forcing women to commit suicide.  The witch's descendant, Martha Gunt, is sentenced to be burned for witchcraft.
As she is placed in a prison cell, Maciste comes forth to fight evil.  When he uproots the cursed tree, he finds an entrance to Hell where he attempts to track down the original witch to rescind her curse and attempts to help the damned from their plight.

story:
After the Civil War, Brothers Dan and Neil Hammond return to Texas and to their parents' ranch. Neil is happy to simply help run the spread, but Dan's ambition is to build an empire, the way ruthless business tycoon Cord Hardin has.
From the moment they meet, Hardin's wife Lorna has romantic designs on Dan. After a series of confrontations between the two men result in Hardin's death, the two become involved. Dan becomes a powerful figure, overseeing a vast enterprise that involves rustling horses and buying up land by taking advantage of lax laws.  He corrupts many officials and makes many enemies.
When the marshal of Austin is relieved of duty due to his association with Dan, Neil becomes the law and a violent showdown between the brothers is inevitable.

story: Landowner Morton wants to expand his property because he knows about oil deposits under the Indian territory. Settlers also come to the area, as a peace treaty with the Comanches provides security. Disguised as soldiers, Morton has his men attack the Indians. Black Eagle, the chief of the Comanche, then digs up the hatchet. After a bloody raid, the village's surviving settlers seek shelter in the nearby fort of Captain Jackson and his men. Due to the peace treaty, however, the fort is undermanned and Jackson is unable to act. He hires trapper Clint McPherson to investigate the cause of the Indian uprising, uncovering Morton's deceitful plan, which he tells Black Eagle. He and the Indians arrive at the fort just in time to assist the soldiers and settlers against the attack by Morton's men.

He appointed Clint McPherson, a trapper, to investigate the origins of the Indian resistance.  McPherson discovered Morton’s deliberate scheme, a deceptive strategy he revealed to Black Eagle. story: Upon being promoted to run the Statistical Section, the top secret headquarters of French military intelligence, Georges Picquart begins to discover that the evidence that was used to convict Alfred Dreyfus of espionage, which resulted in his imprisonment for life on Devil's Island, is flimsy at best. As he investigates further, he discovers that the military and the government doctored much of the evidence. Moreover, the spy who actually passed the information Dreyfus was convicted of sending to the Germans is actually still operating. Warned off the investigation by his superiors, Picquart persists, risking his career and his life, to free an innocent man from unjust imprisonment and to stop a spy operating within the military, who has gone unpunished.
view1: Georges Picquart, newly appointed head of the Statistical Section, began a meticulous examination. His pursuit of this information propelled him into a deeper dive. He stumbled upon a disturbing pattern: the intelligence community had deliberately manipulated the evidence. More significantly, he realized the military and the government weren’t entirely truthful. A crucial element – the individual who delivered the crucial information to Germany – continued to operate.  His warnings were met with resistance; his position was threatened.  Despite this, Picquart resolved to act. He willingly put himself at risk, determined to liberate an individual unjustly imprisoned and to neutralize a spy within the military ranks, one still free from punishment.

story: In 1943, the US Navy ship USS Eldridge disappears, due to the Philadelphia Experiment.  In the present day (2012), researchers try to recreate the experiment, which has the unintended consequence of making the Eldridge reappear, apparently having traveled through time.  The sole survivor of the original experiment is aboard, and meets up with his now-adult granddaughter.  The Eldridge continues to drift through time and space, trapping others aboard it.  The research company attempts to cover up the incident by trying to kill everyone involved.  A struggle ensues as others try to protect the survivors, and return them to their original times and places.

story: The film opens aboard a U-boat as it returns from a mission. It then follows the crew onshore the day before they ship off for their next mission—meeting their family and sweethearts, spending a last night at a club, and so forth. Then they ship off, soon sighting and boarding a Dutch merchant ship, which they inspect for contraband. The boarding of the ship is shown being done professionally and in a non-confrontational manner. While they are aboard the Dutch ship, a Royal Navy ship spots them and tries to torpedo them, but the U-boat ends up sinking it.

story:
Police Officer Alex Kearney is a patrolman in Bryn Mawr, an affluent, plush suburb of Philadelphia--until he stops an important businessman and his account of the incident is not believed. As punishment, he is assigned to work Downtown, considered the most dangerous, high-crime precinct in the city. Everyone at the precinct is certain that the 'by the book' suburban, pampered cop is going to get himself (and whoever is assigned as his partner), killed.
Sergeant Dennis Curren draws the unfortunate 'babysitting' assignment. However, when Alex's best friend is killed investigating a stolen car, Alex throws the book out the window tracking down the killer.
view1:
Alex Kearney, a patrolman, served within Bryn Mawr, a meticulously manicured area of Philadelphia—a place of privileged residences. However, his station was swiftly altered when he encountered a prominent figure and the ensuing details were met with skepticism.  The consequences were severe; he was relegated to the most volatile district, a precinct infamous for its perilous activity. The entire team held a firm conviction: this officer, a steadfast, reliable presence, would inevitably face a brutal end. 

Dennis Curren, a sergeant, received a disturbing task – a ‘consultation’ assignment.  The circumstances surrounding the incident were shaky, and the initial reports lacked credence.  A sudden tragedy, involving a friend’s demise, ignited a furious resolve within Alex. He launched a relentless pursuit, determined to identify the perpetrator. 

Alex, driven by a fierce need for justice, relentlessly investigated. He tracked down the killer, exposing a conspiracy that had concealed its presence. The outcome was a dramatic reversal, a testament to his tenacity.

Alex’s best friend was killed investigating a stolen car. Alex tracked down the killer.

The killer was apprehended. Alex’s friend survived.

story:
Huey Walker (Dennis Hopper) is a hippie and a former New Left radical (in the vein of Abbie Hoffman) who has been on the run from the law for 20 years for something he did not do, disconnecting Spiro Agnew's train car in Spokane, Washington. John Buckner (Kiefer Sutherland) is an FBI agent who is set to transport Walker back to Spokane for trial.
Their journey forces them to cross paths with a corrupt Sheriff Hightower and the two end up fleeing for their lives. As the story progresses, it is revealed that Buckner was raised on a communal farm and that his given name is Free. As Buckner learns to reconcile his past with his present, Walker does as well.
view1:
Huey Walker, a figure of the counter-culture, was a man burdened by a past he desperately tried to escape. He’d been on the run, a consequence of actions he couldn’t erase, a disruption of a meticulously planned train car in Spokane, Washington. The law pursued him, a relentless force. John Buckner, an FBI agent, was tasked with bringing him back.

Their path converged with a Sheriff Hightower, a figure steeped in local politics and deceit. They were forced to navigate a treacherous landscape, a desperate chase. As time passed, a hidden truth began to surface – Buckner’s upbringing was rooted in a communal existence, a life cultivated before his given name. Walker, too, wrestled with his history, seeking a reckoning with his past.

Ultimately, they found themselves fleeing, their lives intertwined in a perilous game. Buckner’s investigation revealed a deeper web of corruption, a system built on shadowed corners. Walker, confronted with the ramifications of his actions, began to understand the weight of his choices. The ending was stark, a testament to their struggle and the lasting impact of their shared ordeal.

story:
In San Juan, Puerto Rico, Madison Taylor (Nicky Whelan) is injured when she's caught in the crossfire of two corrupt cops, Pierce (Tito Ortiz) and Tull (Texas Battle).
Madison wakes up in a hospital and as a witness of one of their vicious crimes, she’s placed under the protection of respected police lieutenant Steve Wakes (Bruce Willis). Madison's misfortune turns into a real nightmare when Pierce and Tull turn up to finish the job, realizing she is the key to tracing them back to the crime.
Trapped and hunted by Pierce and Tull inside the locked-down hospital, Madison desperately calls Wakes for help. But she must use her surroundings to fight back alone during this night of survival if there is any hope of making it out of the hospital alive.

In San Juan, Puerto Rico, Madison Taylor, known as Nicky Whelan, suffered a significant impact. She was caught in the middle of a fierce confrontation between Pierce and Tull, two officers of the local police force. 

After waking from her medical bed, Madison discovered she had witnessed a brutal act committed by these two men – a crime orchestrated with malicious intent.  Her position as a witness quickly led to her being taken into protective custody by Lieutenant Steve Wakes, a seasoned and respected officer.

Wakes’s presence offered a measure of security, but Madison’s situation rapidly escalated. Pierce and Tull, driven by a desire to eliminate her, began relentlessly pursuing her. They believed she held the vital information needed to uncover their criminal activities. 

Inside the sterile confines of the hospital, Madison found herself trapped and vulnerable.  She had to rely on her wits and the limited resources available to her to defend herself.  Alone, she desperately attempted to signal for help, utilizing the hospital’s architecture to her advantage. 

Her desperate plea for assistance was answered by Lieutenant Wakes, who immediately intervened.  Madison, utilizing her environment, began a fight for survival.  She navigated the confined space, attempting to evade the pursuing officers.

story:
Undercover CIA agent Sonni Griffith (Wesley Snipes) travels alone to Romania to expose an arms dealer and stop the sale of a nuclear weapon. When the arms dealer is tipped off to Griffith's identity, he lands himself in prison. Griffith is quickly released by the CIA, only to be given a new mission: to escort a beautiful Russian woman named Nadia (Silvia Colloca) back to the United States.
Griffith soon learns that strong-willed Nadia is being hunted by the very arms dealer that he intended to destroy, but this evil dealer will stop at nothing to get the information out of Nadia that he needs: the location of the $30 million she has hidden that will buy him a nuclear bomb. As the leak within the CIA continues to expose the location and identity of Griffith and Nadia, they must fight the arms dealers to the death to save themselves and the world!
view1:

The dealer, aware of her presence, became entangled in a prison. Surprisingly, Griffith was released, only to be presented with a new directive: to guide Silvia Colloca, a strikingly beautiful Russian, back to the United States.

Silvia proved remarkably resilient, exhibiting a stubborn will. The arms dealer, intent on acquiring her information – the precise location of a $30 million sum – was relentlessly pursuing her. He would employ any means necessary to secure the data. As the CIA’s secrets spilled, Griffith and Colloca found themselves in a desperate struggle, a battle for survival against the dealer’s formidable forces.  Their lives were inextricably linked, threatened by a shared enemy.  The fate of the world rested on their shoulders, a sobering reality.

story: The film is a biographical true story about life of Imadaddin Nasimi, well known throughout the East for his school of philosophy and thought, poems and promotion of moral values in a feudal society. During the 14th-15th centuries, when Azerbaijan was a stage for warring powers and civil wars, Nasimi was the only poet committed to promotion of humanism and moral values inflicting criticism on the ruling system and the society itself. For his intruding role in feudal regimes, Nasimi lived a complex and tragic life. At the end of the film, Nasimi is killed in front of masses as his skin is peeled off while alive.
view1:
Imadaddin Nasimi’s story is a detailed account of his life, a profound exploration of his unique perspective and influence. Set against the backdrop of a turbulent era – the 14th and 15th centuries – Azerbaijan was a battleground of competing factions and internal strife. Nasimi stood out as a solitary figure, a poet driven by a fervent commitment to ethical principles and a desire to challenge established norms. He dedicated himself to promoting these ideals, often criticizing the ruling elites and the societal structures that supported them. 

His actions were fraught with danger, as he consistently confronted the power structures of the time. This dedication to independent thought resulted in a tragically complicated existence.  He met his end facing a brutal execution – a swift and impersonal death.  As he lay dying, his skin was removed, a final, stark display of his sacrifice. 

The film depicts the aftermath, a somber moment of collective grief and remembrance.

He criticized the ruling system and society. He promoted humanism and moral values. He was murdered in front of a crowd. His skin was peeled off while alive.

He meticulously crafted the events, a calculated sequence of moments. The town’s leadership shifted, a red tide gradually pushing aside the white. The green followed, a subtle shift in power. story:
FBI agent Diane Norwood (Carrere) and DEA agent Max Parrish (Griffith) are both in pursuit of the same criminals- a trio of allied crime bosses, and a man named Livingston (Lithgow), who handles their finances. But, instead of working together, the two agents race to be the first to arrest the criminals and seize their millions in cash in order to claim the money for their agency.
After realizing neither one can be beaten or persuaded off the case, the agents reluctantly decide to work together. Despite a great deal of romantic tension, their strong personalities and different investigative techniques frequently clash; Diane, who is thoughtful, serious and by-the-book, is frustrated by Max’s cocky, reckless nature and flippant sense of humor.
Eventually, they discover and must team up with an eccentric assassin (Sutherland) who works with Livingston; the agents’ only link to resolving the case. This unlikely group then works to foil the criminals’ plans.
view1:
Diane Norwood, a dedicated FBI agent, and Max Parrish, a seasoned DEA operative, both faced the same challenge – a criminal operation involving three powerful crime bosses and a man named Lithgow, the financier. They were locked in a relentless chase, a competition fueled by a desire to accumulate a substantial sum of money. 

Initially, their approaches diverged sharply. Each agent felt utterly determined to be the first to capture the perpetrators and secure the stolen assets. They sought to claim the rewards offered by their respective agencies. 

However, a mutual sense of necessity emerged. Despite their initial resistance, they were compelled to collaborate. A complicated connection formed between them, interwoven with an undeniable spark of attraction. Their contrasting methods frequently caused friction; Diane, with her meticulous nature and adherence to procedure, found Max’s impulsiveness frustrating. Max, in turn, often dismissed Diane’s cautiousness as stubbornness.

Their investigation unveiled a surprising alliance. A solitary figure emerged – a skilled assassin, Sutherland, who worked closely with Lithgow. This unlikely team soon realized the crucial role this individual played in thwarting the criminals’ schemes. 

Together, they devised a strategy to neutralize the threat. Their combined efforts proved remarkably effective, allowing them to dismantle the criminal enterprise and recover the stolen funds.

---

The agents discovered Sutherland, an assassin. Sutherland worked with Livingston. The agents and Sutherland formed a team. They foiled the criminals’ plans.

The agents achieved their objective. The money was seized. The agents returned to their respective agencies.

story: A group of Russian mobsters have stolen a huge supply of paper for printing U.S. currency, and are now flooding the market with counterfeit bills. When a young woman named Mickey (Jill Ritchie) working for the mobsters decides to turn herself in and hand over a data CD to the police, she is shot and killed, but not before handing the disc to an unsuspecting Tommy Lee (Phillip Rhee). Despite working with the police as a martial arts instructor, Lee doesn't go to the cops with the disc, but instead goes on the run, giving the mafia time to kidnap his daughter Stephanie (Jessica Huang) to hold as a hostage in exchange for the disc. When Lee catches the mobsters fleeing in a C130, he raises himself on a fire engine and casts the mobster's own bomb into the plane as landing gear doors close.

Subsequently, she was struck by gunfire; her demise occurred swiftly.  However, before she relinquished the data, she handed it over to a man named Tommy Lee (Phillip Rhee).  Lee, a former martial arts instructor, remained elusive.  Instead, he vanished, allowing the criminal organization considerable time to seize his daughter, Stephanie (Jessica Huang), as leverage.  A chase ensued – the mafia’s vehicles pursued the mobsters.  A C130 aircraft swiftly approached.  Lee ascended on a fire engine, initiating a forceful action – he hurled a bomb into the plane’s landing gear.  Doors closed, sealing the fate of the criminals' operation.

story:
Professional cyclist Jacques “Jock” Boyer moves to Rwanda in 2006 to help a group of struggling genocide survivors working to form a national cycling team. The team is composed of children left orphaned and traumatized by the genocide a decade earlier. Over the course of the story, both Boyer and the team "rise from the ashes" of their pasts with the help of their new achievements.
"Team Rwanda" begins as a cycling organization but evolves as organizers realize the athletes' greater needs. Many riders are illiterate and malnourished, living without water, electricity or healthcare, and most are recovering from the psychological effects of the 1994 genocide. Eventually, "Team Rwanda" is viewed as a symbol of hope for Rwanda, ambassadors for the recovering country. In subsequent years, the team expands its vision and develops a model of caring for athletes. In 2012, the team begins developing the first all-African team to match up to the Tour de France after one of the riders qualifies for the 2012 Summer Olympics.
view1:
Jacques Boyer, a professional cyclist, arrived in Rwanda in 2006. He sought to assist a crucial group of individuals dedicated to rebuilding a national cycling program for the survivors of a decade-long genocide. These survivors, bearing the scars of trauma, were tasked with cultivating a team, a collective of children – each carrying the weight of the past.  

“Team Rwanda” began humbly, initially as a simple organization.  However, the team’s needs quickly became apparent. Many riders were lacking essential necessities – they were illiterate and struggling with malnutrition, experiencing the debilitating effects of the 1994 conflict.  Most were grappling with deep psychological wounds, a direct consequence of the horrific events.  The team’s progress was gradual, fueled by small victories. 

Progress unfolded steadily, a testament to their resilience. The organizers recognized that the athletes demanded more than just physical prowess; they needed support, nurturing, and a foundation for recovery.  “Team Rwanda” blossomed into something far grander. The team’s aspirations broadened, and a new vision took root. 

In 2012, the team dared to aim for a significant goal – to establish the first all-African team to compete in the Tour de France. A rider’s participation qualified them for the 2012 Summer Games.  The journey was arduous, demanding unwavering dedication.
